number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
The Cave is a cute little game made by DoubleFine. It is a side scroller point&click, the controls are legacy of both genres and you will have no problem getting into it whether you are more comfortable with one or the other genre.I personally like Point&Clicks and the idea of The Cave in general, everything is fine, descent ambiance, good story-telling (Stunning narrator voice).The game is built around several characters, you will choose three characters for each of your run, and go through The Cave that will lead to different path depending on which characters you choose.The problem is that half of a The Cave run is the same, regardless of which character you choose. The number of character available isn't a multiple of three (That means that you will have to go through the path of two characters two times). That completely breaks apart the idea of a replayable game, because you basically have to go through the same content several time to get the new content (Which is annoying and pointless in a point & click game, it's a repetitive mindboggling grind).If you have the time and patience (I am usually really patient, and I have a lot of time for games, though I hadn't enough) You will probably enjoy all the content of the game, and be really happy with it. If you don't, the game will only offer the third of what you paid for.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												The puzzles in this game are not all that bad - they are in fact the game's one *and only* strength.On the other hand, the puzzles could have been a lot better - they could have been designed with multiple solutions using various character specific abilities that would make you feel really clever to figure out the different ways to solve them. They could have, but they didn't. What a waste.When there were multiple solutions, they too were just lame. There's one point where the scientist can use her 1337 hacking skillz to open a door... or, you could just pull the lever right next to it. Another where the Adventurer can grapple over a pit of spikes... that she could have just jumped over. When you can do something profoundly different (like using the Monk's telekinesis to obtain a guarded item early, or carry an extra hotdog with you for 3/4 of the game to shortcut a later puzzle), it felt more like an exploit of a poorly thought out level design rather than something sneaky you could do as a deliberate design decision by the writer.The writing in this game is just bad - it's clearly trying to be funny, but I don't think I even smiled once while playing, and I certainly didn't laugh. The Cave is sentient and provides a narrative voice, but the voice actor simply reads the jokes off the script in an almost monotonic voice with no emotion whatsoever. The other voice actors aren't much better, but really the problem is that the script is just lame and didn't really give them any room to shine.The story reminds me of the type of work I'd have submitted for high school English (if not worse) - in my mind I could create really interesting characters, with a dark unsettling past that I'd put together in an unusual and interesting setting and have some event spiral out of control of the characters, bringing their best and worst traits out as they had to reluctantly work together to overcome... yeah, what I wrote on the paper was little more than a Star Trek rip off.I can tell that in the writers mind he had developed seven really interesting characters with a dark past that are going to commit some terrible atrocity in the cave - unfortunately the game fails to develop any kind of connection to the characters and we feel absolutely nothing for the characters and no remorse for the evil deed that they do.I'm not nuking the Earth as the Scientist because the game has developed a connection with her and I can see that she believes that it is really her last option to eliminate an oppressive government that only pretends to listen to it's intellectuals as a facade so they can continue pretending that planting a few trees will solve climate change and that dumping three million cubic metres of mining dredge spoil on the Great Barrier Reef won't have any adverse affects (spoiler: it's not actually that interesting, she just wants money).No, I'm simply turning the three launch keys because it's the only way the game will let me progress.The game has good & bad endings for each of the characters, but they boil down to a single choice at the end of the game to take a souvenir (bad ending), or return it to the gift shop (good ending) - that's just lame (as are the chalkboard endings), and it doesn't even let you save before the decision to see the other ending without playing through the entire game AGAIN (MINIMUM FIVE PLAYTHROUGHS TO SEE ALL THE ENDINGS - what a waste of time). They could have had the bad ending be the easy solution to the character specific puzzles (e.g. launch the nuke) and the good ending be a much harder alternate solution to the same puzzle (perhaps the Scientist could have found a way to trick the bad guy with the money into giving the warhead a push because it was "stuck", then swap the warhead with him and launch it into the ocean - the world is saved and she still gets rich), but no, it's just more wasted potential.And speaking of time wasting, can Ron Gilbert please get off his pretentious butt and stop padding his games (which he has done since the Monkey Island games - but at least they had good writing to carry them through) and wasting players time with unskippable cutscenes and forcing multiple playthroughs (THREE MINIMUM) just to play all the puzzles, and even more playthroughs (FIVE MINIMUM) to see all the different endings. And each of those playthroughs requires you to sit through those same unskippable cutscenes again (they aren't very long, but once I've seen them once I really don't care to watch them again, what with the terrible writing and wasting time and all), as well as play a bunch of common puzzles again - not difficult, just a complete and utter waste of time. There is absolutely no reason why the game couldn't have let you take all seven characters on the one playthrough and play all the puzzles (perhaps selecting three for each puzzle or section).If you want an interesting platformer with multiple characters and a good story, go play Trine. It's puzzles aren't as good as The Cave, but it is a much better game overall.If you want a point and click puzzle/adventure game with multiple characters and some really good wit and humour, go play The Book of Unwritten Tales. There are tonnes of really good adventure games coming out these days, just not from the industry "veterans".And, for the love of God can we please stop throwing money at Double Fine on kickstarter? We're as bad as the big name publishers, thinking that they will make good games because just because they had a couple of hits in the past!

content:
Posted: January 27, 2013
												Caves are awesome. They can contain just about anything. Sadly, this one contains a lesson about what happens when you bring a great narrative, and forget about fundamental design. A great idea is wasted with terrible platforming, klutzy level design and tedious puzzle solving. The Cave probably would've worked as an adventure game, but instead it becomes another chapter in Double Fine's struggle to create some worthwhile gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2013
												Ok, I've just finished The Cave, which took me around 4 hours in total. It's... alright. Not great, not bad, just alright.You have a choice of three from seven characters to choose from for your adventure. I took the Knight, the Hillbilly, and the Adventurer. Each playthrough starts the same way and ends the same way, but you have three small "story" sections bespoke to each character, which makes specific use of that character's special ability (the Knight has a shield ability, for example). The story sections are amusing enough and some of the puzzles got me stuck for a while, but overall it just feels a bit... undercooked. It's like it could've been just something a bit more.The style is cool, it's reasonably funny in places, it's just not as good as I wanted it to be. Maybe I've misjudged it and I'm not their target audience, it does have a certain charm to it, I just felt like I was playing through it to complete it rather than to see what the story did.Unless you're absolutely dying to play it - in which case you've probably already bought it - I'd really wait for a 50-75% off sale (probably the latter).TL: DR; there's better Double Fine games available. It's not bad, just not as good as it could've been.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Start out the game and pick a small team out of a bunch of different characters with which you will use to explore various locations in the cave and use their powers to power past a series of different challenges.  The characters are fun and unique and play well with any of the challenges.  The enviroment is very well done and makes for an enjoyable experience to run through.  Each enviroment is very well crafted and presents puzzles that fit those areas and make sense for the characters as well.The game is an enjoyable expierence to run through and the puzzles present enough challenge to be both frustrating and enjoying.

												Beside Gilbert's well known humor and his gusto for art-designs, he did accomplish a truly new step in adventure-game evolution by mixing the its best features with a classic platformer. He also abandoned, what can make both boring. Too much dying in a plattformer and musing without any action about puzzles in adventure-games. He just kept the minimalistic elements and did so create a realy addicting pastime event. I couldn't stop until I was finished and had never the urge to take a look in a walkthrough, I did so often when time took to long to solve a puzzle without nothing other happens meanwhile. This time it was pure fun to jump and climb throughout the levels again and again. Expire it, it's another masterpiece!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Overall I've been disappointed by this game. While the athmosphere and narration are fun, the game just feels a little shallow for what I would expect from a great puzzle platformer. The controls are clunky, and the puzzles are thin (meaning: easy and unoriginal). The designers seem to have tried to make up for this by making the distances in the levels really............... unnecessarily large. You have to walk great distances to pick up an item because there's no inventory system and it's non-obvious which item you should have in hand, which just seems to extend the levels unnecessarily for what are otherwise pretty straight forward puzzles. If you're new to puzzle adventure games this could be a nice gentle introduction, but it's certainly not got the depth that you would want if you've been playing these games for years.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												For us oldsters it's Earthworm Jim meets LucasArts adventures like Day of the Tentacle.Lavish production, hilarious cartoon logic all set in an allegory of... Hell. Can't really be anything else considering... well that's a spoiler, which shows that there's some fun wriing. The cartoon logic is impeccable, e.g. you need the bananas to enable the guidance system... Because the guidance system is a monkey. Take care to inspect everything highlighted, because in all likelihood it will be essential to the plot. Sometimes several layers deep...All too brief (7 hours first run) but there's replay sort of forced on you. You only get to use three characters per adventure, but each of the seven have their own dedicated level.Good for achievement grinding, but starting to lap in about two hours; how many laps to get the last few achievements.I love it, but possibly because of the nostalgia factor, 8/10

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Excellent game for couch co-op.The Cave has a wink and a smirk hidden in all the little details that make this game so great. They found a perfect solution for co-op gaming with the screen not splitting up but switching to the player who claims the "right of control" for himself. The puzzles are not too hard but will still induce strategic discussions. Also a great replay value since you get to choose from different chars with a different unique skill, which will require you to solve the same puzzles in other ways. I wish it had even more "Monkey Island"-ish humor.

												-- This is not a real co-op game, basically only one player will control a character at a time and the other has to wait. The tag is a lie.---- The ladder climbing is tedious and together with revisiting and running around it makes up most of your gametime. This part was just a pure waste of time and makes this game not enjoyable to me.-- The "riddles" are way to easy, and if this game is more about the story than those riddles, then why did the game design make us get and return objects and/or climb ladders for ages?+ Nice graphicsTaking away the time spent on ladder/rope climbing and tedious run-and-get tasks, the play time for a playthrough would end up being 15% of the time. This game is stretched like the backdoor of a pornstar specialised on backdoor porn.  For this reason alone I would give this game a big fat thumbs down. I would not recommend this to anyone except maybe a 10- year old because the riddles are just dumb.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												The Cave speaks, so it introduces it self and presents seven characters that are about to enter it, but you can only choose three of them. They are: The Knight; The Cientist; The Adventurer; The Twins; The Monk; The Time Traveler; and The Hillbilly. You'll be taken on a journey to find what they desire most and what they would do to get it. The cave is divided into seven character themed stages and three unchangable stages that are interconnected. So whenever you play you'll go through three stages based on each of the characters you choose at the start and three that will aways be the same. The Cave is filled with puzzles, interesting stories and a funny narrator. The only problem I have with the game is the fact that to play with three new characters I had to go through the other three unchangable levels and there was still one character left to play with, but this one I watched on Youtube. Overall the puzzles are really good, but some are better than others. I would recommend you to play with the Cientist, the Time Traveler and the Hillbilly, because they have the best stages. Then play with the Adventurer, the Twins and the Monk, which are ok. The Knight has the worst stage, but it is on the start of the cave so you can easily play it as the last character and then watch his endings on Youtube.

												Oh, wow, do I love this game. It reminds me of the kinds of games I grew up with as a child and played over and over again until I could do them perfectly. . . The problem with not having all that much money but having way too much time on my hands as a child. That's first world problems for you.I'm not going to say it's for everyone, though. The humor is rather dry and often at least a little bit macabre (the twins, for instance) but if you like dark humor (which I love) this game will at least be fun for that.There are a few problems. There are some odd glitches every now and again, though they are not all that frequent (unless you're doing the no deaths runthrough, when every deadly glitch rears its ugly head). The biggest problem is that you can't skip any of the cutscenes or dialogue. Don't get me wrong, both are superb in this game (I'm pretty sure Grey DeLisle voices at least one of them, too) but since this is a game that relies on multiple playthroughs, the skip feature really should have been included. I mean, trying to do the no deaths playthrough alone will probably have you just leaving the room on occasion to do other things while you wait.Saying all that, this game is just too much fun to pass up. It's worth the price and if it's on sale, doubly so. Oh, and get the soundtrack because it is fantastic!(Also, I just checked, and Grey actually voices three characters.)

												This game was fun once, but its' replayability is limited. It offers multiple characters who each come with their own levels, but those levels are interspersed with stock levels that you have to run through every time. There isn't enough variation in the characters to make those stock levels interesting on subsequent replays. THe play-through time with one set of characters is also quite short so, while the dialogue and story is fun, the game just isn't that worth it.

number of helpful: 11 of 23 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Many, if not all, cultural phenomena can be traced back successfully to a point of origin, something that Hunter S. Thompson would call a “long fine flash“ condensing the energy of an entire generation, ushering forward the new and unexpected. For adventure games that point was late 80s and the reason was Ron Gilbert with his crew at LucasArts. When the team was busy laying the foundations of an entire genre with Maniac Mansion, my parents were still enjoying a carefree and childless life so, unfortunately, I have missed what some consider the golden era of point-and-click adventure games. Even later on, my path has rarely crossed with the classics, being a primarily console gamer and all, but finally the genre has caught up to me and sparked my interest like not many do (maybe it was the top hat). Finally, upon seeing the trailer for The Cave, the title that Ron Gilbert was returning to adventure games, I knew that fate was giving me a chance to confront the past of the genre and maybe even the future. After finishing the game I’m pretty sure I saw neither.The game starts with the player being greeted by the titular Cave, who will also be the narrator further on, and being given a choice of 3 out of 7 distinct characters with vague names such as The Scientist, The Adventurer, The Monk and so on. Each of the characters not only has a unique ability to them but also an exclusive storyline. Quite soon you will realize that the narration is something different from what we are accustomed to – none of the characters, except the Cave, have any dialogue and their past is discovered by the player in comic book-like pages that are plastered on the walls with an occasional nod or hint from the omniscient narrator. The Cave offers a rather rarely seen exposition by gameplay where you unravel the mysteries by your own actions – and most of them are not what would be generally considered “nice”. You accidentally murder people on your quest to get the treasure, push the switch or any other achievement-trope you can think off which generates an unique feeling of dread of what will the next area and next puzzle bring. The pinnacle of suspense is by far the campaign for The Twins, which presents us with two children determined to break away from their over-loving parents – at all costs (think of Tim Burton when his creative juices were still running). It is easy to spoil what happens in The Cave so I will not go into further details as the stories presented are not exactly complex, yet they somehow latch on to you, as every parable should.The gameplay is broken into 6 areas – 3 unique to their characters interwoven with 3 more general with everybody in your team taking part in the action. As you go further down, the spelunking will take you from an old mine through a monster-infested route up to an isolated island whose only residents are an old hermit, his parrot and his dog (hilarity ensues). The puzzles contained within the sectors, while not very creative or fresh, flow naturally from one to another and very rarely do you feel like your path is being artificially blocked. When you leave the island you have seen the worst side of your back-stabbing, money-grubbing, fame-craving team and you are ready for a catharsis, a moment where you can make all wrongs into rights and somehow redeem your ensemble. Unfortunately, you are thrown to the entrance of the Cave where you uncover the last page of the comic book. The game ends.With 4 hours on the clock you feel cheated, not only by the game time (you still have other characters to play after all) but by the lack of resolution. After all you have went through, it feels like the game-creators have thrown the towel in mid-sentence and called it quits, leaving the player yearning for a proper ending to a story they have witnessed. With each next playthrough the feeling only intensifies. Once again you are forced to complete the same general areas which offer nothing new – not in terms of cooperation which boils down to “have three people pull three levers” and not in terms of using unique abilities to solve puzzles. The platforming, with which the game is abounded, is stiff and rather annoying, not surprising given Gilbert's detest of it. You begin to long for a normal inventory instead of going to-and-fro carrying items one at a time. The character-specific areas feel wonderful and refreshing but once again the crew’s struggles feel futile in the wake of the ending. Even the addition of a “good” ending that can be achieved is meaningless, as it feels tacked on and irritatingly un-final. When you look back on The Cave you see an unpolished gem that, with a bit more work and thought put into it, might be seen as an example of proper gameplay-driven narrative dealing with common, but not trivial, themes. It is a journey that does as much well as it does bad leaving the player with a thirst for more. As for my dilemma – unfortunately it is neither the past nor the future but the present, in all it’s wobbly, uncertain and disappointing glory. http://www.gatheryourparty.com/articles/2013/03/29/the-cave-review/(Do not buy this at full price.)

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												This game is a platformer puzzle, but fails in both styles. There is nothing challenging in the platformer part, no dexterity is required. The puzzle part is like those point-and-click games. But you are faced with only one challange at a time and there are only a couple of items available so the solutions are quite straightforward.For me the real issue was how multiplayer works. Yes, the game supports couch multiplayer, but actually it does not work well. It is part of the puzzles to do something with one character while you leave the others do something else. This means characters can, and often do get off-screen. The result is that your buddy is just watching you as you walk, and walk, and walk, and walk... My daughter was totally bored and quickly abandoned me.All together this is not a bad game but not a good one, either. I, at least, had no joy when the characters reached to bottom of the Cave and had no inspiration to try a different set of characters which would present me some different parts of the Cave.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12
												The Cave is an old school graphic adventure masquerading as a platformer, built with a stylized 3-D environment but lacking meaningful challenge or story.I was a big fan of the Monkey Island series, as well as other point-and-click games under the LucasArts and Sierra labels, so I had high hopes that The Cave would follow in the footsteps of this fledgling genre. Needless to say, The Cave failed to deliver any of the features that made these games fun.The puzzles are nearly all straightforward and lead to few of the "ah-ha!" moments that should have been prominent in such a game. Most of the time required to solve the puzzles involves walking back and forth across each level, and few of the puzzles relate in a meaningful way to any story. The idea of including unique levels for each character chosen is a nice idea, but these character stories aren't particularly motivating or fulfilling. The narrator admittedly has its own charm that can be fun at times. However, the simple premise of "three adventurers wander around in a cave" leaves little for the development of sophisticated humor that intertwines with a farcical yet compelling plot. I miss games like that, and unfortunately The Cave doesn't quite fit the bill.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												I bought this game because it had local co-op.  It turns out the game plays where you alternate characters, so local co-op isn't really people playing at the same time, instead it's taking turns playing (like swapping controllers).  The game is extremely buggy and some of the puzzle solution very unforgiving (e.g. you had to HOLD a button while switching characters to solve one of the puzzles).Furthermore, the endings are all very depressing forcing you to play through the game yet again, with the same puzzles in order to obtain better ones.  I love Double Fine but this is NOT a good game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												As enticing as another double fine game made by the same person who brought you Maniac mansion sounds, I would only recomend this to people who are completly starved for another adventure game. You can take control of a group of three quite unique and well desighned characters from a pool of seven as you lead them to face their dark secrets and gain the one thing they truely desire.The problem with this game come in three factors. One, while the characters look interesting at first glance. you quickly realize that the only view into what make them up is literaly a seven page comic that you find pieces of alonge the way. None of them will say anything about the things and events around them which is a heavy staple in any adventure game. Having differnt people observe the same places that you have to go through every playthough in seperat ways would drastically cut down on the monotonus parts of this game which leads to...Factor number two which is that several of the puzzles while clever are hanpered by long hallway and slow ladders seperating each puzzle piece. This is also compounded by the fact that each member of your group can only carry one item at a time neccesitating constant back and forth even well you do find out what to do. One play through was hard enough which leads to.....Factor number three which is that if you want to get all of the ending comic panels you HAVE to play the game from start to end SIX TIMES. you have seven people to play as each with a good and bad ending which is decided by one final choice and a hidden one at that. Also you would think that playing as new people would change the game drastically but eachs person's dark deed moment is sectioned off into a different stage. I could see which ones I was missing as I passed the themed enterance down the cave.It pains me to pick this game to pieces because I really wanted this to be good. It had a good consept from under used genre. I was even reminded of a lighthearted silent hill as wierd as that sounds because both are about people with dark pasts venturing into a location that changes itself to force that dark secret into the person's face, But it's held back by bad use of the three person mechanic, shallow characters, and tedious puzzles.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												The Cave, made by Ron Gilbert, best known for Maniac Mansion and the first two Monkey Island games, along with many other fun, creative, enjoyable games.I wanted to like this game. That's how it's supposed to work, right? A creator who pioneers an era of video-gaming gets shoved aside for a few years, and he comes back, proving he just needed monetary backing to let his creative energies flow and creates a solid game that showcases his unique vision and proves himself worthy of great respect and consideration.I wanted to experience that... but I did not.The puzzles are fun the first playthrough, and the concept of "different characters can solve the puzzles different ways," filled me with nostalgic glee for the original Maniac Mansion, but it's not to be. The majority of puzzles are the same no matter who you choose. The characters' individual powers only really matter for their individual maps and some token moments. Moreover, most of the characters just aren't that interesting. The Scientist's story was probably the best. The Twins' was at least amusing. But, the rest...The game has multiple endings. The ending you get depends entirely on a choice you make at the very end of the game. You must play through the game a second time to see the other ending. No saving and reloading. This is not how you do multiple endings in a satisfying way. This is just wasting our time.You probably would be better off watching a Let's Play than actually playing the game.

Posted: August 21, 2015
												A quirky puzzle-platformer by Double Fine. The Cave was for me, thorougly enjoyable (I played it with a controller). The game has a lovely art style and a good control-scheme. Gameplay-wise each character has their own little story, with them being combined depending on who you choose, it is well worth replaying to see each characters story!And I know some will want to know about the 30FPS lock. So I'll be honest, I couldn't notice it that much, and I've been someone who is heavily towards the "60FPS or GTFO" camp. I suppose I was ill when I played this game, which may have affected things, but either way I don't feel the 30FPS lock on this should put you off.Well worth the purchase, even at full price!

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Here is how you play the game: you walk with character A along path 1. At the end of path 1 you realize that you need character B here to advance. So you walk along path 1 with character B. Next you walk along path 2 with character C. Now, here you need character A. You walk path 1 backwards to reach the end of path 2. You walk back the paths with all three characters consecutively to follow path 3 to the exit... did this description bore you? Well, if so you know what it is like to play this game. Besides this painfully boring repetitive walking around there is not much to say about this game. The story is OKish but nothing special (no great sense of humor or such). The puzzles are mostly fair, but (again) nothing special. The only positive thing about this game is that the artwork is really nice.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2013
												The Cave is a fun yet flawed adventure game. One that challenges the mind though does not make it explode. With an underlying story about morality you'd expect the worst, but it's a fairly enjoyable journey. With a party of three out of seven possible characters, you descent down the Cave. Each character has their own dark secret, their own unique ability and one exclusive section inside the Cave.That basically means you have to play through the whole game three times to max it out. That would have been okay, if not for the recurring puzzles which can't be skipped, resulting in slow and repetitive gameplay, really hurting replay value. While giving a worthy challenge and raising a few laughs - its one of the more original and creative games in a while. Yet its falling short on so many aspects, you can't help but feeling this game could have, and perhaps should have, been so much better. +Original and creative+Funny+Challenging and lots of 'But of course'-moments+One playthrough won't leave you satisfied (but a third for one new puzzle might not be worth it)-Clunky controls-Slow, mandatory puzzles on replays-Bugs (I've encountered a LOT)-Some graphic issues -A bit too short6+/10

												8/10Amazing game, I'd consider it a must-play for any fans of puzzle games. Puzzles are creative, the stories for the different characters are interesting and there's a lot of good humor in the game, thanks to the narrator.7 characters, 2 endings for each and the cave paintings makes sure this game lasts for quite a while, but that's also the one flaw in the game: lack of replay value. A single playthrough is pretty short and since the puzzles are always the same and there aren't many optional activities in the game, there isn't much reason to go back to this game once it's fully completed.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2013
												Well I had high expectations for this one. Its meets many of those expectations without any doubts. Wonderful visuals without having to drift backwards in graphics quality.  Seems many old school adventure game developers feel that in order to get that old school feel the graphics need to suffer. In this case it proves you can have both classic gaming wrapped in charming graphics.  Very interesting twist having 7 characters to choose from, each with their own unique skills or special abilities. This goes along with a lot of the more recent adventure style games requiring multiple characters. One needs to be sent to hold a certain lever, another to pull on something else while the 3rd is there to accomplish the task. Each of 7 characters has a special gift or ability. The adventurer had her lasso in order to swing from over head features while the "Twins" can leave phantoms of themselves in place. Overall a great title, certainly does not disappoint. Puzzles are hard to enough to keep me interested. Very little if NO hand holding with this one. One thing the screenshots dont do justice to just how charming and nice the graphics are. Very well done title.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I can recommend this game to Adventure players, however only barely, 6/10. It has some nice puzzles, good voice acting (mostly narrative), and some dark humor. The game centers around 7 different characters, from who you can take 3 with you per playthrough. There are ca. 7 puzzle sets per playthrough, that means 4 common ones which are identical in every playhtrough, and 3 which are character specific. And there lies the big problem of the game... you need at least 3 playthroughs to see most of the game (although in the 3rd playthrough, only 1 of the 7 puzzlesets is still new and unique!) an there is a lot of backtracking. You even need 5 complete playthroughs to get all achievements/see the whole story, although only 1% is still novel, and that is quite boring. It was already a chore for me to do 3 playthroughs, thats all I will do.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												I typically love Double Fine's games, but this was a great disappointment.  The dialog and art style are the two good qualities this game offers.  The frequent backtracking regarding puzzles, need to repeat the game multiple times for completion, and obtuseness of some puzzles (or ease for some) are only some of the negatives.The worst part of my experience (having played this one and one half years after release) was the game-breaking bug of one of my characters falling into nothingness and being deleted from my three available slots.  This left me unable to continue in the game.  The only thing left for me to do is to restart from the beginning which I will not be doing any time soon as replaying these puzzles is tedious at best.As an aside, while the game allows for multiplayer, this may as well be reduced to pass and play with a controller.  This is only a single player game despite what it may be advertised as.I would have a difficult time even recommending this game if it were free, and I wish this weren't the case.  There is too much wrong to ignore.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Cool design and funny story telling, but the game play is very unintuitive in areas. The puzzles seem to be all over the board with not a lot of hints on what you should be doing, tho overall its a find key open door concept for most things.The game has different areas, some seem based on the characters and others are inaccessible, perhaps trying to promote replayability by picking the other available heroes a second time. No real tool tips on why you should pick certain characters to start off.The game overall has a nice design and I will probably finish it eventually, but at times it seems forced to be multiple games in one, too all over the board, hard to get imersed in to the world or the game play with 3 characters if you compare it to something like Trine.Edit:Just got the the end, and there is no ending, you are basically encouraged to start over with other characters, which in turn will make you replay about half of the same game play to once again, get to no ending. While I am a fan of the publisher, I just think this one was poorly executed.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												While the idea of transitioning between 3/7 characters through a magical cave that creates worlds base on each their psyche was interesting, the execution was very disapointing. After my first playthrough I got to admit it was pretty fun, but the next two runs got boring and repetitive since your force to play through the same puzzle areas just to get the new part of the cave thats base on a different character you choose. The worse part in playing this is on the 3rd run you not only force to do the same puzzle areas but the same two character special areas with nothing new to challange you whatsoever just to get to the last area you have not explore.  Each characters in the game have a special trait in which to solve different puzzles. unfortunately they can only use them productively in their own special world thus making them unreliable when it comes to the  regular repetitive puzzle areas we all love so much. honestly the creaters could have made a better game if they allow us  to choose any of the seven characters on the fly and explore the whole cave in one run with added puzzles that requires more than one of their special abilities. I did enjoy the visuals, story, and voice acting since it reminds me of nightmare before christmas, Overall I say it's better to pass since it's a reptitive grind just to experiance the whole game. It would have been fine if they made it a one time playthrough with extra levels that extands the use of their abilities. Your better off watching a walkthrough online if your only interested in the story.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Were it not for the destinctive art-style; the poor controls, weak writing and dull gameplay would never suggest that this was a Double-Fine game. While co-operative gameplay may be different, playing alone will require you to make the same journey to the next puzzle for each of the three characters you control, meaning a minimum of 3-times for one-way, 6-times if you need to double-back (and you likely will), and any number more if you get stuck. This game offers little more than repetition and traversing the more-or-less linier path, which is rendered a chore by the clunky and innacurate controls. If you're looking for a fun, beautiful, side-scrolling action-puzzler, you're far better off with Trine (which also offers 3-player co-op).If you're a die-hard fan of Double-Fine, as I am, give it a go. There are nods to your favourite games and glimmers of that humor we all love (not to mention the beautiful drawn-art and character design), yet within an hour I was bored and frustrated, and by two I'm writing this, not expecting the experiance to improve. Do yourself a favour and get a copy of Brutal Legend: a visually stunning and rich world full of action, humor and emotion that this game seems devoid of.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												The Cave does not value your time. It's a short game, yet still manages to feel tedious. Most of The Cave's puzzles have pretty obvious answers, but due to its awkward platforming and one-item-per-character carrying system, you'll spend more time meandering around than anything.There are 7 characters with unique stories, and you can take 3 with you. Meaning you will have to play the game 3 times to experience everything, with at least one repeat character during your second/third playthrough. You will replay content. Regardless, it's not particularly fun the first time through, and I definitely wouldn't recommend it for a second or third time.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												I'm just going to be blunt here because this game speaks for itself. To describe it in one sentence would be "One big glorious shared masturbation between Tim Schafer and the other Double Fine guys and every single one of their fans".The way I see it, this is like Psychonauts but with the focus entirely on dialog and character development. It's also what Psychonauts would have been like if it were not for EA and LucasArts being moral watchdog pieces of♥♥♥♥♥♥ It explores pretty dark motivations and is not afraid of showing fairly brutal murder that the cartoony aesthetic makes more grim for some reason. Especially because of how The Cave reacts to it so non-chalantly. He's seen this cycle repeat for thousands of years.This is where the spoilers start. From what I can tell The Cave is a purgatory of sorts. Characters are stuck in a loop of reincarnation and retreading their paths until they can not be total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and be redeemed. It really makes the playthroughs seamless from both a story and technical standpoint.Speaking of technical standpoint, from the perspective of a programmer I am absolutely in love with this game for a few reasons. Firstly, it uses Buddha (appropriate name hm?) which as far as I can tell is an engine that Double Fine wrote for their stuff in house and uses Lua as an extension language. They used it for Costume Quest and probably Stacking and others. I deeply admire and respect when people write engines that are reusable and aren't just marketing throw-aways. Damn shame that Double Fine is keeping it proprietary though.Besides that, the story justifies the reuse of game assets marvelously. It uses mostly the same map but with minor changes for each character that opens pathways and other branches. It gets a little bit repetitive when you're doing the generic transition levels but still. I rarely see such a robust way of extending a game in a non-intrusive manner.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine The Cave is a game developed by Double Fine Productions and published by SEGA. Now I'm not usually a fan of puzzle games unless done right but I must say I enjoyed The Cave. The game is charming, funny and cleverThe animations of the each individual characters, music and voice acting is awesome and well produced. The premise of the game is that there are seven characters and you pick three of them at the begining of the game and try to get them out of the caveEach character has a different story, a unique skill and their own levels. In order to get everyone out of the cave you need to play it at least three times. If you want to see everything the game has to offer (there are two endings for each character) you need at least five playthroughsThis may sound boring, but puzzle solving in this game is really fun. Also depending on your characters and the items you picked along the way, you can find some shortcuts in some certain levelsLong story short, even if you're not a fan of the genre, I say give The Cave a chance, it is a wonderful little indie game! RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: February 17, 2013
												Just don't. Shoddy 30 fps framrate cap. Plays like a console port from unexperienced developers, definitely not something I would expect from Double Fine. Also, the game mechanics are horrible, in order to get all seven stories you have to replay two of them and the whole system of charachter switching feels bulky and unbecoming of any puzzle game. Speaking of puzzles, this game has two types of puzzles, the ridiculously hard ones that take 20 minutes to figure out that you have to use the games clunky mechanics to throw a sausage on a spike, and the ones that are so easy that you feel like, why am I even wasting my time? In my opinion, till they fix the bugs, fps cap and shoddy mechanics, this is NOT worth 15 dollars.

Posted: November 13, 2013
												The Cave is a new adventure game from Monkey Island and Maniac Mansion creator Ron Gilbert, and Double Fine Productions, the award-winning studio behind Psychonauts and Brütal Legend.Assemble your team of three from seven unlikely adventurers, each with their own unique personalities and stories, then descend into the mysterious depths to explore locations including a subterranean amusement park and a medieval castle, not to mention a fully armed and ready-to-launch nuclear tipped ICBM. The Cave awaits.

Posted: August 15, 2013
												A fantastic puzzle-platformer!  Just as good as The trine games (if not better)!  Very smooth cartoon graphics, a cast of 7 diverse, playable characters.  Each character has a unique abilty as well.  My favorite aspect of the game is how each character has their own "level" can only be played when you have them in your party (only 3 in your party  per playthrough), so you can't experience the full game in one playthrough.  Now you're probably thinking "I don't want to have to play the game more than once". The beauty of this though is that it each playthrough feels different, because you're not replaying it in the same sequence and learning new things ech time you have a new character.  Another great feature is that you can only solve certain puzzles with specific characters because their abilities are rquired.  Don't worry though, you can always progress!  Anyway, my first playthrough took me about 5+ hours, and I'm currently on my second.  I hope to see some more amazing and challenging puzzlers like this in the future!P.S.  The narrator is the actual cave that you are traversing.  The story is cheesy, but also very funny at times.  Just get it PERIOD  ^_^

Posted: June 19, 2014
												A fun and interesting game, that I have played a lot.It has problems sure, but I really do enjoy it.The dialogue is great, the level design is fun and creative, and I really love that you actually avoid entire sections of the game if you bring certain characters or items along. (Hint bringing an item from earlier in the game will allow you to completely avoid the zoo section)For instance my first time playing, I brought along the Monk, Scientist, and Knight. I ended up using the Monk's Ability to get through the Knight's section, which was nice but the next time I had the Knight with out the Monk, I had to actually figure out how you were supposed to actually do it. The music is also fantastic, and I will definitely get the soundtrack one of these days. It is slightly annoying that you have to play through the entire game to get a new "ending", but I really like what happens when one of your characters get the bad ending, because it was really affective in making me feel bad for getting their bad ending.

Posted: June 20, 2013
												There are six different characters you can play with, but only 3 are available at one time. You pick those characters at the beginning and you keep those 3 for the duration of the game. These characters allow you to go into certain areas, but the other areas will be closed to you until you beat the game and play with other characters. You really have to play the game 2-3 times to beat all the areas. It's a really neat puzzle story in a cave. But the cave is reaaaaaaaaaally big.

Posted: May 1, 2014
												I... like it.It's a simple, short puzzle platformer that's basically mediocre all around.But! The concept is pretty neat.Basically: you assemble a team of 3 adventurers who are seeking what they desire most inside "The Cave".To get it, they have to reach the bottom. Along the way, they must relive and overcome the most horrible deed they committed throughout their lives. You get bits and pieces of their past as you go along, all coming together for everyone in the end. You can play through it multiple times for everyones endings (there's a good and bad one for everyone) but the most annoying part of the whole game is that there's seven playable characters total. You can only take three at a time with you.The playthroughs get pretty short once you know what to do in every level, but doing the same damn thing again and again gets pretty boring.Basically, you'll only really enjoy this game for the story bits, (but if you want to see everything, be prepared to do the same things over and over) everything else is very bland. It also looks pretty sometimes, I guess.

Posted: March 31, 2014
												The Cave is a great point-and-click adventure, well drawn and excellently scripted.  You select three "heroes" to make your way to the bottom of a cave, each of them searching for something along the way.  The puzzles are tricky, the jokes are laugh-out-loud funny, and the characters give the game a perfect touch of dark humor.  There're several amusing easter eggs from other games for the keen eye.  My biggest problem with The Cave is when I compare it to a similar game.Choosing three of seven available characters took me back to thoughts of Maniac Mansion.  If you are a fan of that game, you will be a little disappointed in the fact that different combinations do not mean different ways to defeat the game.  Each character has a unique stage to be played through, with common areas between them.  While the character's unique skill will be used in their own stage, the other characters are simply warm bodies used to solve a plethera of puzzles.  This lack of diversity also hurts replay value, since I haven't played since I beat the game with all seven characters.Aside from this one setback, I thoroughly enjoyed The Cave, and recommend this light-hearted yet sinister tale to all.

Posted: April 27, 2014
												Hello once again. Alright I think it's time to shed some light on this game that's gone unnoticed by many gamers.     The Cave is one of those funny, indie puzzle/platformer types of games. It immerses you into it's story with different characters you can pick. You find pictures, or you can go scavenging for them. These pictures will tell you about the character. It is quite grim in the sense that the stories are all of hatred and darkness, and just sins. Yet still it is a fun game that is narrated by a quite talented narrator. The comedy is nice and I love it for that. So what are you waiting for? Get your asses over here and buy this damn game!

												Enjoyable graphics and sound (+effects). A quite nice variety of characters to choose. Though I would prefer a few more to be added. Decent riddles and puzzles. Not too hard or too easy for me but just right.

Posted: December 10, 2015
												The start of this game creates an immersion unlike any game I've played.  There are no loading screens.  It features a tutorial that teaches you how to play while allowing you to progress.  Unfortunately, this game has very little replay value.  Each character gets their own unique level, however all of the transitions are identical to one another.  After your first play through, the mandatory tutorial becomes tedious.  Until you reach a new character's dedicated level, the transitions become a grind.I very much hoped for a Spelunky-like procedural level generation at least in the transitions between each character's static rooms, but I was let down.  Much of this game is static and repetitive, though it is certainly very good looking.  I wish the developers would have put more resources into making the game playable more than once rather than making it shiny.Wait for a sale, I wouldn't recommend paying more than $5 for this game.

												Very fun platformer and with the exception of the dark humor, is a great game for the family.  It has a very good atmosphere and rich graphics.  One minor gripe is that we got stuck on 2 spots because of the very specific button combinations needed even though we were doing the right thing (mine car switch and prehistoric boulder).

Posted: January 28, 2013
												What is The Cave? Choose your 3 hapless adventurers (from a group of 7) and you will find out soon enough. Easily playable in one sitting, The Cave is more a short story than a novel. It is whimsical, colorful, at times laugh-out-loud funny. The puzzles are challenging, but never tear-your-hair-out difficult. Think outside the box and you will go far. If you enjoyed Maniac Mansion (and who didn't??) or Psychonauts, you will get a lot of enjoyment out of this game. There are more than a few nods to players of both of those games.

Posted: February 3, 2014
												The Cave - I find it hard to place this game in a genre...As a platformer it is clunky and devoid or difficulty or depth.As an adventure game it is too disjointed, with each short episodic section entirely unrelated to the last.I guess you could call it a puzzle game, but although the puzzles make sense they're a far cry from the likes of monkey island.There was one redeeming chapter in this game *** SPOILERS *** that used a time-travel mechanic, but (to cut a long story short) the player has just a 3 in 7 chance of seeing this in their first playthrough!And you're not coming back for a second try... This game is full to the brim of artificial gameplay lengthening!The only saving grace is the Stanley-Parable-esque narrator, but the jokes aren't *that* funny. The macabre mood helps, but they pulled their punches too much to keep things kid-friendly.I'd suggest it only as a gateway game for kids... but our kids are worth more than this. [3.8]

Posted: February 11, 2014
												Before I get into my complaints about this game, I just want to make it clear that I did, overall, really enjoy playing this game and would happily buy the sequel if they ever get around to making one.  The game play reminded me a lot of the old Vikings games, minus the perma-deaths, where you had to rely on the abilities of more than one person to get a job done.  The character levels and the “transition” levels (those stages usually between the character specific ones) were pretty fun and the puzzles, while not that hard, did give my brain a little exercise.     I won’t even bother gush over the art style or script for this game because you’d have to be made of stone not to like them.      This all being said, I did have a few problems with it.  First off, seven was not the lucky number here, it should have been nine.  The reason for this is that, by the time you get to the third round of the game, you have now exhausted playing all but a single character.  This means you have to repeat at least two people’s levels.  Knowing exactly what to do makes for a less fun experience the second or third time around.  I say “third time around” because of my second complaint.  I would have loved to see this game provide more than three “transition” stages.  Again, the ideal number would have been nine.  If the game designers had given each character their own transitional stage, then you would have never felt like you were playing the same game twice.  Tedium is the worst enemy of the “one solution only” adventure game.  If you have already solved the puzzle once, what value is there in solving it exactly the same way again?Of course, even after saying that, I would still recommend this game to anyone who wants an excuse to laugh and enjoy a few hours running around a sentient cave.  Just remember, sometimes your greatest desires can be your own worst enemy.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												Much of what I have to say about the Cave has been said in previous reviews, but I think it bears repeating in addition to some other things I've noticed.The story is an amusing one of dark humor, the graphics visually appealing, the music subtle and fitting, the controls easy and relatively smooth. The puzzles are simple and fun, but can get frustrating at times because of the lack of direction/clues/whatever you want to call it, which sometimes makes it hard to figure out where to start without referencing a guide. As people have said, there is a lot of repetitiveness, and there is a lot of running back and forth in many of the puzzles which at times can be frustrating if you don't have a lot of patience like myself. I never found myself having a problem working with the three characters per se, but at times it is annoying to only be able to carry one item at a time (which relates back to the running back and forth part). Having seven characters to play through with is certainly annoying by the time you reach the last one, because as people have noted, this means you have to redo all the puzzles for two of the characters you've already finished with. I definitely agree that for the most part the replay value is not very high, however, after playing it today for the first time in about six months, I found myself plesantly surprised at my renewed interest. The game has great potential and it's a bummer that nothing really gets switched up from runthrough to runthrough. I really enjoy the games that Double Fine puts out because they are simple but entertaining, with a colorful cast of characters and a little bit of snark and wit in the stories. I think despite it's flaws, the Cave still holds true to all of that. (And the scientist, time traveler, and adventurer are all women, which was a fun bonus perk for me because you don't often see women in those roles in games. None of that affects gameplay, but I still thought it was rad.)Overall, I would recommend the Cave. Maybe a 7 out of 10.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												I'm on my first playthrough with my first three characters, and all the reviews I've read have been on point: it's a beautiful game and the puzzles are easy enough to keep the pace going (there's nothing like that "aha!" moment), but the environments are too big. I didn't think that would be a problem (because I like exploring), but when you need to navigate the same series of sprawling passages over and over again to solve a puzzle -- especially when it's a trial-and-error puzzle that involves a prop you need to re-collect every time you fail -- you start to wonder what the developers were thinking. All the running around gets frustrating, which leads me to the walkthrough page faster than I'd like: if I've got to do so much ditch-digging just to try something that I don't know will work, I'd rather spoil it for myself.But I still recommend the game if you know what you're in for. It's a light puzzler with a dark sense of humour, and the visual design is breathtaking.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												The Cave is less of a full fledged adventure game and more of a compartmentalized adventure game. You choose 3 of 7 characters to enter the cave and each character will have their own puzzle level with 3 constant puzzle levels that the player must always play through.For the old school adventure aficionados, the Cave won't be a challenge and may not live up to the experiences of games such as Monkey Island. For the rest the Cave sits as an enjoyable puzzle game with simple control schemes and interesting puzzle levels.There are 7 total characters each with a different special ability, the only issue I have with the abilities is that most of them are really only used in their specific levels, otherwise some of the abilities are pretty useless through out the rest of the game. There are characters that will allow you to get through certain puzzles quicker than normal but no puzzle requires a character outside of the main character for that story. Each character has their own story to tell, mostly told through their own level as well as through the storyboards that you pick up throughout the game. Due to only being able to play 3 characters at a time, multiple playthroughs of the game are needed to see everyone's ending. This only causes problems when you have to play the default puzzles that always show up in the game. It would have been better if there was say 6 default puzzles and 3 random ones would be dropped in everytime you played to keep the player guessing as to which puzzle was next. I got bored of the default puzzles real quick after playthrough 5 and up.The main dialogue in the game comes from the Cave itself and is really well written. Sure you'll get bored of it after playing through the game several times but on first play through it's enjoyable to listen to.The Cave is an adventure game worth playing but don't come in expecting it to replicate the old school adventure games.

Posted: December 31, 2014
												I didn't buy The Cave immediately when it was originally released and this is mainly because I'm not a Ron Gilbert, Tim Schafer, or Double Fine fanboy. I like all of those things, but the only Ron Gilbert game I ever played was Maniac Mansion (which was great, but I was like 8 years old), and both Tim Schafer and Double Fine have shown me that they can do as much bad as good sometimes (cough ... Brutal Legend .. cough). I did eventually acquire The Cave though and having finally played it, found I enjoyed it.Right up front, the presentation of this game is top notch. The art, controls (I used an Xbox controller), and sound were excellent. The core conceit of the game design (choosing 3 out of 7 characters to go through the cave) I felt was a bit lacking though. The game makes concessions for your not having certain characters (and their abilities) with you and with the exception of completely optional cave painting unlocks and very minor shortcuts, your choice of characters is purely narrative. This isn't horrible, but it means you'll have to play through the game 3 times to get all the character stories and content, repeating the non-character specific areas of the game each time.The actual control of the multiple characters works rather well and for the most part the puzzles designed to rely on them are interesting as opposed to frustrating. My one gripe with the controlling multiple characters is the backtracking that takes place for each one in many instances. While there are checkpoint-like locations where the two other characters will instantly appear at the side of your controlled character in order to alleviate the tedium of treading the same ground again, some puzzles still require going back and forth through the same area with two or more characters in order to solve a puzzle.In the end, The Cave is a pleasant blend of adventure and puzzle genres with what I would consider to be an entry-level to intermediate difficulty. What it may lack in complexity it makes up for in charm and I'd recommend it if you're looking for a mild puzzler with good personality.

Posted: June 12, 2015
												Players choose three of the seven available characters, each with unique talents. I'm currently playing with a knight who has the power of invincibility; an adventurer who can swing a grappling hook; and twins who have the ability to duplicate themselves. When you access special areas of the cave, you uncover scenes from your characters' pasts. Also, each character has a special quest that occurs in a unique area of the cave. (The knight is tasked by a king to defeat a dragon and retrieve an amulet for his daughter.)You switch control between the three characters as you advance through the cave. Often, teamwork is required as you must position the characters in certain areas or have them perform tasks simultaneously. There are monsters, but there is no combat. Instead, you must figure out how to get past monsters with strategy alone. For one early example, you "battle" a dragon with a hot dog and a claw like those found in an arcade game.Controls are simple, consisting of moving side to side, jumping, climbing, and picking up and using various objects. Characters can only hold one object at a time, and certain objects are needed to advance through different areas of the cave. Because it's not always obvious which objects must be used, you will often find yourself doubling back to retrieve dropped objects. This is a new type of game for me, so I've found myself running around aimlessly quite a bit, experimenting with different combinations of characters and objects to try to advance.So far, I've experienced no glitches. What I have experienced are clever puzzles, beautiful visuals, and a game that will lend itself to re-playability as I will want to try out all of the characters.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												The Cave is less of a full fledged adventure game and more of a compartmentalized adventure game. You choose 3 of 7 characters to enter the cave and each character will have their own puzzle level with 3 constant puzzle levels that the player must always play through.For the old school adventure aficionados, the Cave won't be a challenge and may not live up to the experiences of games such as Monkey Island. For the rest the Cave sits as an enjoyable puzzle game with simple control schemes and interesting puzzle levels.There are 7 total characters each with a different special ability, the only issue I have with the abilities is that most of them are really only used in their specific levels, otherwise some of the abilities are pretty useless through out the rest of the game. There are characters that will allow you to get through certain puzzles quicker than normal but no puzzle requires a character outside of the main character for that story. Each character has their own story to tell, mostly told through their own level as well as through the storyboards that you pick up throughout the game. Due to only being able to play 3 characters at a time, multiple playthroughs of the game are needed to see everyone's ending. This only causes problems when you have to play the default puzzles that always show up in the game. It would have been better if there was say 6 default puzzles and 3 random ones would be dropped in everytime you played to keep the player guessing as to which puzzle was next. I got bored of the default puzzles real quick after playthrough 5 and up.The main dialogue in the game comes from the Cave itself and is really well written. Sure you'll get bored of it after playing through the game several times but on first play through it's enjoyable to listen to.The Cave is an adventure game worth playing but don't come in expecting it to replicate the old school adventure games.

												I'm on my first playthrough with my first three characters, and all the reviews I've read have been on point: it's a beautiful game and the puzzles are easy enough to keep the pace going (there's nothing like that "aha!" moment), but the environments are too big. I didn't think that would be a problem (because I like exploring), but when you need to navigate the same series of sprawling passages over and over again to solve a puzzle -- especially when it's a trial-and-error puzzle that involves a prop you need to re-collect every time you fail -- you start to wonder what the developers were thinking. All the running around gets frustrating, which leads me to the walkthrough page faster than I'd like: if I've got to do so much ditch-digging just to try something that I don't know will work, I'd rather spoil it for myself.But I still recommend the game if you know what you're in for. It's a light puzzler with a dark sense of humour, and the visual design is breathtaking.

Posted: July 28, 2014
												Not even on a Steam SaleFirst the good stuff: Art and character designThis game has a whimsical art style and can be a fun cross between puzzles and light platforming, with particularly funny narration and character design.The bad stuff: Poorly executed forcing of replayThe game punishes users for indulging in that whimsy. The game forces painfully slow backtracking as you figure out a puzzle. Funnily enough, what's worse is when you can't backtrack: Because you frequently pass points of no return accidentally and the game autosaves, you can't have fun exploring an area you've completed because you risk losing access to collectibles or missable achievements. If that is a part of gaming you enjoy, it pretty much forces you to play with a guide open to keep you from missing anything, completely devaluing the collectibles and achievements.However the most aggregious, avoidable design sin is tha for each playthrough you select 3 out of 7 characters (I'll say it again: Three) to take through the campaign, which changes three character specific levels to the game. Did you catch that? The selection of three out of seven? If you are going to obligate replays like this, why not have a number of playable characters that is divisible by three!? This is infuriating and since several puzzles in the cave are permenant fixtures, not character specific, this means you have to play through some puzzles 3 times, and other puzzles (for the two characters you'll play twice) 2 times. Getting all achievements demands a total of 5 playthroughs, but by then you'll have lost all interest.There are some great indie-like titles on Steam, I encourage you to find them instead of buying this one, regardless of the price.

Posted: July 13, 2014
												I think the most impressive feature of this game can be found in the multiple choice set up.  Choosing from seven characters you pick three and switch between their skills – e.g. teleportation, a brief moment of immortality, Telekinesis, etc. –  to travel through the cave and ultimately "survive" the game.  Characters each have their own backstory which are experienced through areas assigned to their stereotypical being.  As the adventurerer you will find yourself in a pyramid recovering a sarcophagus while, as the Monk, you search for enlightenment in a temple.  All of the above enables you to replay this game without experiencing déjà vu – which is a main reason why many of my games end up on a high shelf – so you can still experience different stories after your first time.  In terms of tone, The Cave is a dour adventure – existing through puzzles – but you can still find yourself grinning by the quirky humour of the cave and the lively gameplay.  The puzzles are never unbearable or difficult.  Given, they aren't difficult at all and constantly having to switch between characters can get weary but, eventually, the game's design and concept makes up for that.  The game will save you some time as you can't leave behind a character due to a lack of switching.  You can either go no further wihout the help of another character or if you are too far ahead they'll eventually follow you to where you are.  The variation in character skills and environments also helps.  Summed up, The Cave is great if you're looking to have some casual fun.  It won't challenge your mind.  You'll find yourself in a world where everything is turned into a joke – sometimes subtle or even cruel – yet the story is well constructed and narrated.  All that through the enjoyable voice of Stephen Stanton. Because after all, you experience the stories through The – speaking – Cave, which on its own is a cheerful concept.  It's a matter of whether you can enjoy a charming, casual game.  Don't expect challenging puzzles and levels that need a large amount of time.  This game can be seen as a piece of art, something to enjoy, rather than something you have to fight through.  8/10

Posted: August 25, 2014
												The Cave isn't a hard game to recommend, it has a charming art style, some brilliant voice acting, and a focus on interesting characters that has been somewhat lost in gaming recently. I doubt that you'd be surprised to hear that this game was developed by Double Fine, as the Psychonauts-esque zaniness and humour remains present in this title.The game is not without its peeves though. Take for example the fact that there are 7 characters with unique stories, yet you cannot adventure with more than 3 of them at the same time. This means playing through the game 3 times, once with 2 characters you've already played with, left as irritating third wheels. What's more, each character has a good ending and a bad ending, which means playing through the game more than once with each character anyway in order to obtain all the endings (Which I wouldn't personally recommend doing, seeing as the endings change very little) There are even several default levels in-between the character driven story levels, which you have to play every time, and playing through these levels becomes tedious very quickly, as you are often forced to backtrack in these stages.Despite all this, I'd recommend this title. Maybe not full price, but on sale, it's a no-brainer purchase.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Growing up, I was always a fan of the old LucasArts adventure games; especially the Monkey Island series.  In my opinion, they're some of the funniest, smartest, most entertaining games ever written, even if they sometimes leave you wanting to throw your computer out the window in frustration while trying to figure out exactly why you've had a rubber chicken with a pulley in the middle in your inventory for game hours.The Cave, having been developed by Ron Gilbert and Tim Schaffer's studio, Double FIne, manages to capture some of that charm in a simple yet challenging puzzler.  One playthough takes right around 4-5 hours to complete (depending on how good you are are solving adventure-style puzzles, I guess), and is different depending on which mix of characters you choose to lead through the cave for that session.  Throughout each playthrough, you'll experience a mix of both "common" areas (areas that you may encounter regardless of which characters you choose), and character specific areas with puzzles that require the use of that character's special ability to solve.  There is a dark, sarcastic sense of humor that weaves a thread through the entire game, and these character areas, which serve to flesh out the characters' individual back stories (sparse as they may be), are no exception.  Fans of the adventure genre, especially the LucasArts games, will find lots to love here.  Aside from the puzzles themselves, there are a ton of small touches throughout the game that pay homage to Gilbert's earliest titles, especially Monkey Island and Maniac Mansion.  The puzzles are, in my opinion, fairly straightforward, though they may take a little time to figure out.  Some other reviewers complained about the lack of direction in the game regarding how to solve the puzzles.  I don't get it--this genre has always been about making the player figure out what to do without too much help from the game itself.  In my opinion, that's always been core to the experience of playing these types of games.  The feeling of accomplishment is much greater when you figure out a particularly challenging puzzle on your own, rather than relying on a cascade of hints.  But, I digress.Having only completed one playthrough so far, I can't comment yet on the game's replayability.  It seems to be there, as different mixes of characters provide a different experience, but I can see how replaying the same common areas over and over again could get old.  All in all, I'd give the game an 8/10.  The style, art direction, and writing are excellent.  At the current Summer Sale price of $7.49, it's well worth a purchase if you're a fan of adventure games, or even looking for something that's a little different that can kill a few hours here and there.

Posted: February 11, 2014
												Before I get into my complaints about this game, I just want to make it clear that I did, overall, really enjoy playing this game and would happily buy the sequel if they ever get around to making one.  The game play reminded me a lot of the old Vikings games, minus the perma-deaths, where you had to rely on the abilities of more than one person to get a job done.  The character levels and the “transition” levels (those stages usually between the character specific ones) were pretty fun and the puzzles, while not that hard, did give my brain a little exercise.     I won’t even bother gush over the art style or script for this game because you’d have to be made of stone not to like them.      This all being said, I did have a few problems with it.  First off, seven was not the lucky number here, it should have been nine.  The reason for this is that, by the time you get to the third round of the game, you have now exhausted playing all but a single character.  This means you have to repeat at least two people’s levels.  Knowing exactly what to do makes for a less fun experience the second or third time around.  I say “third time around” because of my second complaint.  I would have loved to see this game provide more than three “transition” stages.  Again, the ideal number would have been nine.  If the game designers had given each character their own transitional stage, then you would have never felt like you were playing the same game twice.  Tedium is the worst enemy of the “one solution only” adventure game.  If you have already solved the puzzle once, what value is there in solving it exactly the same way again?Of course, even after saying that, I would still recommend this game to anyone who wants an excuse to laugh and enjoy a few hours running around a sentient cave.  Just remember, sometimes your greatest desires can be your own worst enemy.
