Posted: February 3, 2014
												My experience with Double Fine's games are that they tend to be equal parts hit and miss. The hit is usually in the concepts, and the miss will be in the execution. This game's no different.This game is basically a hybrid between a point & click adventure and a platformer, with a party of 3 characters running around at once, and many puzzles based on using 2 or 3 at the same time. Said party of 3 gets stuck in a sentient, talking Cave, which challenges them to learn a valuable life lesson. Failure implied not escaping from the Cave. The concept is interesting, the art & music also work well. It's all remniscent of a brighter version of Tim Burton's puppet movies. It also has a dark sense of humor, and some exploration is required to get the full story on the characters you're playing with. That covers the hits.The problems lie in the execution:Each character has a special ability, and a special section of the cave dedicated to them. Sadly, those sections are also the only bits where the different abilities really matter. Outside, there's a few points where you can use them, but there's always a generic solution close-by that renders the different abilities mostly obsolete.As a minor gripe, the game also doesn't offer any real hints that the special abilities exist, unless you open the "How to play" option in the menu.The controls for the platforming also feel sloppy at times, not a huge distraction as there's no real precision jumping etc. involved - the adventuring is definitely the dominant gameplay. But it can get annoying at times.The most baffling design choice though, is the fact that despite death having no penalties, you can easily fall to your "death"  anyway. This really serves no point, and just results in lost time as you turn into a puff of smoke and float back to a previous checkpoint.Overall: recommended if you're a fan of point'n'click adventures and want to play one with a twist. If that's not your thing, you'll probably want to pass on this though.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												Much of what I have to say about the Cave has been said in previous reviews, but I think it bears repeating in addition to some other things I've noticed.The story is an amusing one of dark humor, the graphics visually appealing, the music subtle and fitting, the controls easy and relatively smooth. The puzzles are simple and fun, but can get frustrating at times because of the lack of direction/clues/whatever you want to call it, which sometimes makes it hard to figure out where to start without referencing a guide. As people have said, there is a lot of repetitiveness, and there is a lot of running back and forth in many of the puzzles which at times can be frustrating if you don't have a lot of patience like myself. I never found myself having a problem working with the three characters per se, but at times it is annoying to only be able to carry one item at a time (which relates back to the running back and forth part). Having seven characters to play through with is certainly annoying by the time you reach the last one, because as people have noted, this means you have to redo all the puzzles for two of the characters you've already finished with. I definitely agree that for the most part the replay value is not very high, however, after playing it today for the first time in about six months, I found myself plesantly surprised at my renewed interest. The game has great potential and it's a bummer that nothing really gets switched up from runthrough to runthrough. I really enjoy the games that Double Fine puts out because they are simple but entertaining, with a colorful cast of characters and a little bit of snark and wit in the stories. I think despite it's flaws, the Cave still holds true to all of that. (And the scientist, time traveler, and adventurer are all women, which was a fun bonus perk for me because you don't often see women in those roles in games. None of that affects gameplay, but I still thought it was rad.)Overall, I would recommend the Cave. Maybe a 7 out of 10.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												I'm on my first playthrough with my first three characters, and all the reviews I've read have been on point: it's a beautiful game and the puzzles are easy enough to keep the pace going (there's nothing like that "aha!" moment), but the environments are too big. I didn't think that would be a problem (because I like exploring), but when you need to navigate the same series of sprawling passages over and over again to solve a puzzle -- especially when it's a trial-and-error puzzle that involves a prop you need to re-collect every time you fail -- you start to wonder what the developers were thinking. All the running around gets frustrating, which leads me to the walkthrough page faster than I'd like: if I've got to do so much ditch-digging just to try something that I don't know will work, I'd rather spoil it for myself.But I still recommend the game if you know what you're in for. It's a light puzzler with a dark sense of humour, and the visual design is breathtaking.

Posted: July 28, 2014
												Not even on a Steam SaleFirst the good stuff: Art and character designThis game has a whimsical art style and can be a fun cross between puzzles and light platforming, with particularly funny narration and character design.The bad stuff: Poorly executed forcing of replayThe game punishes users for indulging in that whimsy. The game forces painfully slow backtracking as you figure out a puzzle. Funnily enough, what's worse is when you can't backtrack: Because you frequently pass points of no return accidentally and the game autosaves, you can't have fun exploring an area you've completed because you risk losing access to collectibles or missable achievements. If that is a part of gaming you enjoy, it pretty much forces you to play with a guide open to keep you from missing anything, completely devaluing the collectibles and achievements.However the most aggregious, avoidable design sin is tha for each playthrough you select 3 out of 7 characters (I'll say it again: Three) to take through the campaign, which changes three character specific levels to the game. Did you catch that? The selection of three out of seven? If you are going to obligate replays like this, why not have a number of playable characters that is divisible by three!? This is infuriating and since several puzzles in the cave are permenant fixtures, not character specific, this means you have to play through some puzzles 3 times, and other puzzles (for the two characters you'll play twice) 2 times. Getting all achievements demands a total of 5 playthroughs, but by then you'll have lost all interest.There are some great indie-like titles on Steam, I encourage you to find them instead of buying this one, regardless of the price.

Posted: August 25, 2014
												The Cave isn't a hard game to recommend, it has a charming art style, some brilliant voice acting, and a focus on interesting characters that has been somewhat lost in gaming recently. I doubt that you'd be surprised to hear that this game was developed by Double Fine, as the Psychonauts-esque zaniness and humour remains present in this title.The game is not without its peeves though. Take for example the fact that there are 7 characters with unique stories, yet you cannot adventure with more than 3 of them at the same time. This means playing through the game 3 times, once with 2 characters you've already played with, left as irritating third wheels. What's more, each character has a good ending and a bad ending, which means playing through the game more than once with each character anyway in order to obtain all the endings (Which I wouldn't personally recommend doing, seeing as the endings change very little) There are even several default levels in-between the character driven story levels, which you have to play every time, and playing through these levels becomes tedious very quickly, as you are often forced to backtrack in these stages.Despite all this, I'd recommend this title. Maybe not full price, but on sale, it's a no-brainer purchase.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												"In this life, we have to make many choices. Some are very important choices. Some are not. Many of our choices are between good and evil. The choices we make, however, determine to a large extent our happiness or our unhappiness, because we have to live with the consequences of our choices." -James E. FaustOkay, besides from quotes from BrainyQuote, you probably clicked on this review to see if "The Cave" is any good. Well...it can be argued. The Cave is a puzzle solver follwoing 7 adventurers and there quest in The Cave. You'll pick 3 out of the 7 at the start, and play the whole thing with those 3. That's my first gripe with The Cave, it essentially makes you play it 3 times if you want to know all the storys. Yes, there's change in each story, but it is not worth playing 3 times. And, if you passed basic math, you'll notice that 7 isn't divisible by 3, so one character you'll have to play again. I think The Cave should of just given you all 7 to play as, and maybe only take 3 into an area. My first, and most likely only, playthrough I took the Twins, the Hilbilly, and the Time Traveler and still thought that I got what I paid for. Story telling is what The Cave excels at, giving you snipits of a characters backstory at a time. It's intresting to see how screwed up everyone is, and makes you want to find out more.Then there's gameplay, and it's a typical puzzle game. Click this, click that, maybe click that. If you're lost, you play the "Does this go with this, this, or this" game, seeing as there isnt a hint system. The only thing negative I can say is that jumping is a little wonky. You'll want to jump to a ledge and accidentally fall to your death. Oh, you die from tall falls, so watch out. Overall, The Cave is just...alright. Is it $15 alright? Ehhhh....do your research. Look into gameplay of it, maybe watch a walkthrough of one person's story. Though, if you love puzzle solvers, buy this.

												The graphics and sound of the game is in a bit goofy, cartoonish style. But it all comes together really well. I enjoy the idea as well as how they set things up to remind you visually that you're still in that cave even though the setting may change.The gameplay is more tricky than I expected. The hints are subtle and smooth, easy to miss if you're distracted outside of the game and not paying attention. Could be one of the reasons why it become so satisfying. Most things can be solved with some common logic though, the rest may need some goofy logic which makes it pretty amusing.The humor is definitely a big reason to why I enjoyed this game. Always able to smile every now and then at silly or stupid comments makes this game great.The only downside I can see is the constant running distances, both back and forth, which feels like I'm just wasting time. The design of the area makes it enjoyable in a way, but not sure if it's enough for me to make it feel worth it to pass through there several times while just running... not sure if it need to be that spacious.Great game overall though which kinda makes up for it.I definitely recommend it for people that enjoy puzzle games with humor.

Posted: March 1, 2016
												TL:DR A pretty decent puzzle/platforming game from Double Fine. Only major downside is having to complete multiple playthroughs to get all the different characters endings as the game gets a bit repetitive after playing through a couple of times.Probably not worth it at full price but a good buy if its on sale.Full Version:The Cave is a platforming puzzle game that has you controlling 3 different characters, who you pick from a group of 7, that you can switch between and control to complete the various puzzles and sections you encounter. The characters are all different (Monk, Knight, Scientist for example) and each one has a unique ability. They also each have their own backstory which is told via slides you collect as you go through the cave with the resolution(good or bad) being obtained when you complete a playthrough. The Cave itself is the setting (as well as the narrator) with your route through it depending on the 3 characters you pick at the start. There are two types of sections you'll go through. Generic ones which you'll have to go through on each playthrough, and the unique ones with each character having a unique section each and are dependant on which ones you choose. The gameplay itself is pretty simple with most of the puzzles not being too difficult to solve as well as the fact that you cant die because as The Cave puts it "Nobody dies in The Cave".Good points:-the dark humour in this game is quite enjoyable and it has its funny moments- the cartoon style of graphics fits the game quite well and the way the level design all ties in togther is quite cleverBad points:-to playthrough with every character will take 3 playthroughs with another 2 if you want the good and bad ending for each character. While this isnt too bad because of the unique sections for each character, the sections that you have to playthrough every time do get boring.

However the characters are weird but entertaining, the story is slightly engaging, its relatively slow paced, and the graphics are good. Posted: June 12, 2015
												Players choose three of the seven available characters, each with unique talents. I'm currently playing with a knight who has the power of invincibility; an adventurer who can swing a grappling hook; and twins who have the ability to duplicate themselves. When you access special areas of the cave, you uncover scenes from your characters' pasts. Also, each character has a special quest that occurs in a unique area of the cave. (The knight is tasked by a king to defeat a dragon and retrieve an amulet for his daughter.)You switch control between the three characters as you advance through the cave. Often, teamwork is required as you must position the characters in certain areas or have them perform tasks simultaneously. There are monsters, but there is no combat. Instead, you must figure out how to get past monsters with strategy alone. For one early example, you "battle" a dragon with a hot dog and a claw like those found in an arcade game.Controls are simple, consisting of moving side to side, jumping, climbing, and picking up and using various objects. Characters can only hold one object at a time, and certain objects are needed to advance through different areas of the cave. Because it's not always obvious which objects must be used, you will often find yourself doubling back to retrieve dropped objects. This is a new type of game for me, so I've found myself running around aimlessly quite a bit, experimenting with different combinations of characters and objects to try to advance.So far, I've experienced no glitches. What I have experienced are clever puzzles, beautiful visuals, and a game that will lend itself to re-playability as I will want to try out all of the characters.

Posted: May 10, 2014
												It is a puzzle solving game that reminds of the old Monkey Island days.The Cave, which is the main character, serves as a guide as you explore its depths. There are 7 different characters to play with, each with his/her own abilities and backgrounds. You must choose 3 of them and enter the cave to discover their true nature, and help them cooperate to survive.The game is handled with a very good, and dark, sense of humor, and alternative paths depend on what characters you pick, adding replayability.The game is very well done, and there are very clever puzzles in it. Well, we should not expect less from Ron Gilbert. The drawings are amazing, and the designers paid great attention to details. The music and sounds are simple but add a lot to the experience, and the voice acting is top notch.I did not give 5 stars because the game itself is very short. Moreover, even when playing with a new set of characters, there are parts of the cave that are repetitive. Maybe if they had done more sections that could be played by all characters and made them appear randomly, it would have added a lot of replay value, and would have made it more fun to try to get everyone through.Target audience: Casual players. It is too easy for hardcore gamers, though it can be enjoyed by anyone.

Posted: July 11, 2015
												This was an enjoyable play. Graphics are well done and narrative is humourous & whimsical. Although there are times where dialogue with in-game characters can get annoying when you're running back and forth trying to figure things out. Puzzles were unique and challenging. However, the time travel level, I found, was a little far fetched so it took me a while (and some hints) to get through that one. There were some levels too, that became monotonous & time consuming due to backtracking by having not chosen the appropriate character for a particular task or just simply trying to find clues on what you needed to do. I do like the fact you had to choose the character best suited to solve a particular part of the puzzle and that you can get through the most levels with whichever 3 characters you choose. Some levels aren't available if you don't have the characters to get through them, but you can always go back and replay with new characters - which is nice.  All in all, I would definitely recommend playing. It was fun!

Posted: March 1, 2016
												TL:DR A pretty decent puzzle/platforming game from Double Fine. Only major downside is having to complete multiple playthroughs to get all the different characters endings as the game gets a bit repetitive after playing through a couple of times.Probably not worth it at full price but a good buy if its on sale.Full Version:The Cave is a platforming puzzle game that has you controlling 3 different characters, who you pick from a group of 7, that you can switch between and control to complete the various puzzles and sections you encounter. The characters are all different (Monk, Knight, Scientist for example) and each one has a unique ability. They also each have their own backstory which is told via slides you collect as you go through the cave with the resolution(good or bad) being obtained when you complete a playthrough. The Cave itself is the setting (as well as the narrator) with your route through it depending on the 3 characters you pick at the start. There are two types of sections you'll go through. Generic ones which you'll have to go through on each playthrough, and the unique ones with each character having a unique section each and are dependant on which ones you choose. The gameplay itself is pretty simple with most of the puzzles not being too difficult to solve as well as the fact that you cant die because as The Cave puts it "Nobody dies in The Cave".Good points:-the dark humour in this game is quite enjoyable and it has its funny moments- the cartoon style of graphics fits the game quite well and the way the level design all ties in togther is quite cleverBad points:-to playthrough with every character will take 3 playthroughs with another 2 if you want the good and bad ending for each character. While this isnt too bad because of the unique sections for each character, the sections that you have to playthrough every time do get boring.

Posted: October 18, 2016
												I love most of the Double Fine games, but this one missed the mark for me.My main issue is that you will spend 90% of your time just backtracking to pick up a different item.  The game limits any given character to holding only one item at a time.  This often means you might walk all the way from one end of a level to the other, only to realize you need the item you left at the complete opposite end.  Many sections only allow you to control 1 character at a time, so there's no real way around this issue.  Yes, without the 1 item limit the game would take WAY less time, but it would also be WAY more enjoyable.  I'd much rather have breezed through the "possible" 3+ playthroughs for each character than be annoyed to the point I didn't even want to finish the first one.If that doesn't sound like something that would bother you, there's a lot to enjoy here.  Classic Double Fine writing, interesting enough characters, and a few clever puzzles that spark that classic adventure feel.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												Do you want to play casually? Great, step right up and play a silly adventure puzzle platformer that will probably make you question whether or not you're playing the good guys the entire time.However, if you want to 100% the game, you're kinda screwed. Every time you play it you get to choose three characters to come with you. These choices change what three stages you have to make it through to get to the end. The first time you run through each character's stage it's a fun puzzle to figure out and escape. The second time you are mostly just annoyed that you have to go through the steps again. The third time you hate every second of it. To get every achievement you have to run through twice with every character and a minimum of three times with the hillbilly. This quickly becomes even more torturous when you then have to make it through the entire game without dying once with any of your characters. This is nearly impossible, and usually ends in you making it all the way to the end of the game and accientally falling off something and having to start over after three hours of grueling gameplay came up for naught. I have played every character at least seven times, trying desperately to make it through without a death. I gave up after a particularly annoying death in which I was at the actual end of the game, after each of the stages, and I managed to fall off the ladder and die. Uninstalled, never looked back.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												It's been a couple of years since I played this game, but I still wanted to write a review for it because I thought it was great and still have strong memories of playing it. The Cave is a puzzle scroller underscored by a dark playful humor as it uses the common environment of 'the Cave' to tell the individual stories of the sins and tragedies of seven mysterious figures. Each character has a special ability and many sections of the map can only be accesed with these special abilities. The means that despite being all contained on one map, the route you take through the map is determined by the characters you play. This creates great replayability as you revisit areas with different skills and discover entirely new areas. On top of that, the routes themselves are themed around the character stories thus giving the playthrough a linear storybook quality that unfolds as you complete puzzles. In fact the puzzles you complete tend to echo the character background stories. Each play through is about 2.5 hours but expect to play the game at least 3 times. The concept and execution are well married making this a fantastic game.
